Comment: This is my first annotation of a game which was not mine. There is general agreement that the mainline of this gambit begins after the following 11 moves. But even here the middlegame is not defined, as Black can castle in either direction. It has become increasingly clear that Black's compensation for his pawn is long-lasting.
The traditional treatment is to go queenside, but in recent games the patient approach with kingside castling has been revived.

This move prepares for white's g4 move, and the Two Knights Defence looks quite strong.
Gambit attempting to move the Bishop, similar to the Evan's Gambit.
Gambit attempting to move the Bishop, similar to the Evan's Gambit.
Gambit accepted and pawn regained.
Now both sides are pretty much fully developed. Only problem for Black is the open file in front of his King. Can be easily defended though with his Bishops and two Knights.
h5!? Now Black is pressuring White's kingside.
Qa4?! 17.Qb3! a6 18.Nxc6 Bxc6 19.Nd4 Bd5 20.Bc4

Black is in quite a worrying position due to the white's knights.
Black is in quite a worrying position due to the white's knights.

Qxf6? Here is where Black missed his chance. Kholmov came up with the following line: 19...Qe4! 20.f3 Qxe3+ 21.Kh1 Qxe2 22. Qxb4 Rd2! 23.Qf4+ Ka8 24.Nc7+ Kb8 25.Nd5+ (25.Nb5+=) Ka8 26.Ne3 gxf3 27. gxf3 Re8 claiming compensation for the piece. In a book in 1984, Leonid, Shamkovich and Schiller extended the analysis further: 28.Rae1 Bxf3+ 29.Rxf3 Qxe1+ 30.Nf1 Ree2 31.Qc7 (Bh4 Rxh2+!)
